questions.text: In a patient with chronic meningitis, the presence of (1,3)-b-D-glucan in the CSF implies that the underlying infectious agent is which of the following?
questions.solution: (1,3)-β-D-glucan is a cell wall component of several fungal species, so its presence in the CSF is a useful adjunctive test in establishing that the agent responsible for chronic meningitis is a fungus, but a positive result does not permit identification of the particular fungal species. Of note, (1,3)-β-D-glucan is typically not present in the CSF of patients with cryptococcal meningitis.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis in a patient with the below EEG finding in a 64 year old male who presented with cognitive decline and myoclonus over past 4 months duration ?
questions.solution:
1. The EEG is showing diffuse slowing and 1-Hz periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs).
    A typical EEG in sporadic CJD has sharp or triphasic waves (periodic sharp wave complexes, or PSWCs) occurring about once every second ; this EEG finding, however, is found in only about two-thirds of sCJD patients, typically only after serial EEGs and often not until later stages of the illness

questions.text: Asymmetric onset of rigidity, dystonia, myoclonus, and apraxia of one limb is often associated with ?
questions.solution: CBS is a slowly progressive dementia-movement disorder associated with severe degeneration in perirolandic cortex and basal ganglia (substantia nigra and striatopallidum). Patients typically present with asymmetric onset of rigidity, dystonia, myoclonus, and apraxia of one limb, at times associated with alien limb phenomena in which the limb exhibits unintended motor actions such as grasping, groping, drifting, or undoing. Eventually CBS becomes bilateral and leads to dysarthria, slow gait, action tremor, and a frontal-predominant dementia

questions.text: In September 2021, the FDA approved which of the following medications for the acute treatment of migraine ?
questions.solution: On September 2021, FDA approved dihydroergotamine mesylate nasal spray (Trudhesa; Impel NeuroPharma) for the acute treatment of migraine with or without aura in adults.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents for evaluation of episodic weakness and headaches. He has experienced five episodes of hemiparesis over the past 3 years. The episodes last 6 to 12 hours and are manifested by spreading weakness from the left arm to the left leg. During the episodes, he generallydevelops a progressively intensifying moderately severe, throbbing headache with associated nausea. His sister and mother experience similar episodes. Neurologic examination is normal. Mutation in which of the following genes is most likely responsible for his presentation?
questions.solution: This patient is experiencing recurrent episodes of hemiparesis progressing over a number of hours. The episodes are associated with headache. The most likely diagnosis is hemiplegic migraine. Because the patient also has a family history of similar episodes in his mother and sister, his syndrome would be characterized as familial hemiplegic migraine. There are three known genetic mutations associated with familial hemiplegic migraine. The most common is a mutation on the voltage-gated calcium channel CACNA1A. Others include mutations in the sodium channel SCN1A and ATP1A2.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man developed diplopia and unsteady gait that grew progressively worse over 2 days. On examination, there is symmetric paresis of upgaze, inability to abduct either eye, and about 50% limitation of adduction of the right eye. There is moderate dysrhythmia of fine finger movements and rapid alternating movements of the hands, and pointing is inaccurate. Gait is extremely unsteady. Strength is normal throughout, but deep tendon reflexes are absent. This patient's serum is most likely to contain which of the following antibodies?
questions.solution: This patient’s clinical syndrome of diffuse bilateral ophthalmoplegia with areflexia and ataxia is typical of Miller-Fisher syndrome, which is associated with serum anti-GQ1b antibodies.

questions.text: Which drug approved for Alzheimer's disease in June 2021 is a humanized monoclonal IgG1 antibody directed against the mid-domain of the Aβ peptide ?
questions.solution: Solanezumab is a humanized monoclonal IgG1 antibody directed against the mid-domain of the Aβ peptide. It recognizes soluble monomeric, not fibrillar, Aβ. The therapeutic rationale is that it may exert benefit by sequestering Aβ, shifting equilibria between different species of Aβ, and removing small soluble species of Aβ that are directly toxic to synaptic function.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with hypertension, hepatitis C, and chronic liver dysfunction has had two focal seizures with secondary generalization thought to be related to a remote cerebral infarction. Which of the following antiepileptic medications would be best to try first in this patient?
questions.solution: Of the antiepileptic medications listed, all but levetiracetam would be relatively contraindicated in a patient with significant liver disease given that they are hepatically metabolized

questions.text: A 35-year-old man reports brief but severe attacks of stabbing pain over his left eye lasting for 2 to 3 minutes occurring on a daily basis for the past 3 weeks. The pain attack is followed by complete resolution, although another attack may occur immediately afterward. In general, the headaches occurfrom 10 to 20 times per day without a clear diurnal pattern. Just prior to the pain, he notices that his left eye becomes red, although he does not notice any tearing. His left eyelid does, however, appear somewhat swollen during attacks. An MRI of the brain is normal. Which of the following medications would be most likely to be effective in treating this man's headache disorder?
questions.solution: This patient most likely has a short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with cranial autonomic features (SUNA), like short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT) only without both conjunctival injection and tearing. Characteristic features of SUNA seen in this case include brief but rapidly recurrent severe stabbing pain with ipsilateral autonomic features without a response to sumatriptan. Given this, the medication most likely to be effective would be lamotrigine. Lithium is used to prevent cluster headache, while indomethacin is useful in treating hemicrania continua and paroxysmal hemicrania. Prednisone could be considered for bridge therapy in treating cluster headaches.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with diffuse weakness and fasciculations, prominent facial twitching, and gynecomastia should be tested for mutations in the gene for which of the following?
questions.solution: Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy, an X-linked disorder caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the androgen receptor gene, typically presents in adulthood. It is characterized by weakness, fasciculations, prominent facial twitching, and symptoms of androgen sensitivity, including gynecomastia and reduced fertility. Most patients also have sensory nerve involvement.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman began to experience numbness, tingling, and weakness in her feet 3 months ago, and it rapidly progressed to the point where she now has severe weakness in all limbs, bilateral footdrop, and calf atrophy. Her examination is notable for skin hyperpigmentation and hypertrichosis, hepatomegaly, lymphadenopathy, diffuse weakness, distal sensory loss, and areflexia. Electrodiagnostic studies are consistent with demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy. Serum protein electrophoresis reveals an IgG lambda M protein. Which of the following blood tests is most likely to be abnormal?
questions.solution: This patient has polyneuropathy, organomegaly, monoclonal gammopathy, and skin changes, four of the features of POEMS (polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, monoclonal plasma cell disorder, and skin changes) syndrome. Most patients with this syndrome have levels of VEGF that are more than 5 times normal values

questions.text: A Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which of the following accumulates in brain?

choices.text: Schedule an urgent temporal artery biopsy

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden painless vision loss in her left eye. She reports increased fatigue over the past month and pain in her jaw muscles while chewing. On examination, she has temporal tenderness on the left. Her visual acuity is 20/30 in the right eye and 20/400 in the left eye, with a prominent left relative afferent pupillary defect. Her left optic disc appears pallid and edematous, while her right disc is normal. She has inferior visual field loss in the left eye. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 80 mm/hr. Which of the following is the most important next step in this patient's management?
questions.solution: This patient’s constellation of symptoms, signs, and laboratory results is highly suggestive of arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy due to giant cell arteritis. Given this, it is very important that steroid therapy be initiated immediately. Temporal artery biopsy should be undertaken in all patients suspected of having giant cell arteritis, given the long-term risk of steroid treatment in the population at risk. However, scheduling of the biopsy is less important than immediate initiation of high-dose steroids, especially in patients in whom vision loss has already occurred. Tocilizumab is an adjunct to and not a substitute for immediate steroid treatment.

questions.text: Norepinephrine to epinephrine requires which amino acid?

Your patient is a 15-year-old girl who was sent home from school because she had a fever of 101°C, a severe headache, and was falling asleep in class. When her fever rose to 104°C, her mother took her to the emergency room, where a blood pressure of 60/22 and several petechial haemorrhages were found. Gram-negative diplococci were seen in a Gram stain of the spinal fluid. Which one of the following is most likely to cause the fever, hypotension, and petechial haemorrhages?
questions.solution: Gram-negative diplococci causing meningitis in adolescents are Neisseria meningitidis. The symptoms of meningococcal meningitis are those of a typical bacterial meningitis, namely, fever, headache, stiff neck, and an increased level of PMNs in spinal fluid along with purpura/petechia.

questions.text: Your patient is a 10-year-old girl with a fever and a severe headache for the past 2 days. Pertinent history includes swimming in a pond near their home in rural Bihar in August. On examination, nuchal rigidity was observed and a lumbar puncture was performed. The spinal fluid white blood cell count was 12,300 with 80% neutrophils. Microscopic examination of a wet mount of spinal fluid revealed motile trophozoites. Of the following, which one is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Naegleria trophozoites usually enter the body through mucous membranes while

an individual is swimming. They can penetrate the nasal mucosa and cribriform plate to produce a purulent meningitis and encephalitis that are usually rapidly fatal. Diagnosis is made by finding amebas in the spinal fluid. The prognosis is poor even in treated cases. Amphotericin B may be effective in Naegleria infections.

questions.text: A patient of schizophrenia was started on haloperidol. Next day, he presented with uprolling of eyes. Complete neurological examination revealed no spasticity or any other abnormalities. Visual acuity and ophthalmoscopy findings are normal. Most likely diagnosis is?

A 4 yr old preschool male child was referred to the neurology department with complaints of spacing out frequently at home and sudden falling incidents while walking. The mother of the child also reports that her son suddenly goes rigid with stiff neck during sleep. EEG showed slow spike wave patterns as depicted in the below illustration.

Choose a drug from the following list that was solely approved for the management of this disease.
questions.solution:
Lennox-Gestaut syndrome is a catastrophic epileptic encephalopathy of childhood for which effective treatment options are limited.

Rufinamide, a triazole derivative, structurally distinct from other available anti-epileptic drugs. It enhances slow inactivation of voltage gated sodium channels. It was approved in 2008 by the FDA as an adjunctive treatment of seizures associated with Lennox-Gestaut syndrome in children 4 years and older and in adults.

questions.text: Mood stabilizers alternative to lithium used in bipolar mood disorder are all of the following, EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Alternate drugs to Lithium with mood stabilizing properties include

  • Valproic acid
  • Carbamazepine
  • Lamotrigene
  • Gabapentin
  • Topiramate
  • Olanzapine
  • Risperidone
  • Quetiapine

questions.text: A 10 years old girl presented with growing left sided neck swelling, as given in the image. The swelling was firm and non-tender. She had freckles and flat spots on the face and trunk. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• There are two distinct Neurofibromatosis syndrome where Schwann cells form tumors.
  • 70% are Autosomal dominant and 30% arise from sporadic mutations.
  • NF 1 (Von Recklinghausen’s disease) is the commoner variant, affecting approximately 1:4000 births.
  • It arises from a gene mutation on chromosome (Ch.) 17.

Skin manifestations appear in early life, with the development of more than five smooth surfaced café-au-lait spots, subcutaneous neurofibromata, armpit or groin freckling and Lisch nodules.

Ref. Bailey 27th Edition Page 595

questions.text: 45 years old male had sudden severe headache and sudden neck rigidity. The CT image shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The History is clear-It’s due to rupture of Berry Aneurysm – there is Subarachnoid haemorrhage happening which is characterised by Sudden Head ache and Neck Stiffness. The CT Scan image shows the Hemorrhage in Subarachnoid space.

Order of frequency

  • Anterior communicating artery: Anterior cerebral junction— most common site
  • Posterior communicating artery: Internal carotid junction
  • Middle cerebral bifurcation
  • Intracranial carotid bifurcation
  • Vertebrobasilar or basilar bifurcation

Multiple in 20–30% cases

Predisposing factors: Smoking and hypertension

Ref. Bailey and Love 27th edition page 659

questions.text: Mr Kumar, 40 years male, a known smoker developed a thunderclap headache suddenly and collapsed. What is the etiology?
questions.solution:
• The bleeding due to rupture of berry aneurysm results in thunderclap headache.
  • 1/3rd of the patients die even before coming to hospital.

questions.text: Grade of glioblastomamultiforme:
questions.solution:
• Gliomas are divided into: WHO 4 grades:
  • Grade 4 is the worst of all gliomas and it is Glioblastoma multiforme and is the most common primary brain tumor in adults

Ref Bailey and Love 27th edition page 664

questions.text: In an old patient after complete excisionof Glioblastoma, what should be donenext?
questions.solution:
• After surgery for Glioblastoma multiforme we must give high dose focused radiation therapy, and chemotherapy administered locally as carmustine wafers at time of resection.
  • Systemically Oral Temozolomide is given**

Ref Bailey and Love 27th edition page 665)

questions.text: According to Spetzler Martin Grading System for AV malformations, the score of a AV malformation of size 3-6 mm with deep venous drainage and location near internal capsule is
questions.solution:
• Spetzler-Martin Grading System is used for AVM grading in Brain.
  • This grading helps in management also.
  • Grade varies from 1-5 based on the following points: Size, Location and Deep venous drainage.
  • Lower score has good outcome.
  • Grade 1 AVM would be considered as small, superficial, and located in non-eloquent brain, and low risk for surgery.
  • Grade 4 or 5 AVM are large, deep, and adjacent to eloquent brain.

questions.text: A man presents with multiple painless swelling all over the body and coffee brown patches in trunk. The condition is
questions.solution:
• Neurofibromatosis is a condition arising from Schwann cells.
  • 2 types are seen
  • 70% are Autosomal Dominant, 30% are sporadic.
  • NF 1 ( Von Recklinghausen) is the MC type.
  • It is due to Gene mutation of Chromosome 17
  • Skin manifestation develop in early life

- Multiple nodules

- Lisch Nodules

- Cafe au lait spots- More than 5 in numbers

- Armpit of Groin Freckles

(Ref: Bailey and Love 27h edition Page 595)

questions.text: A 45-years old male patient presented in the casualty with two hour history of sudden onset of severe headache associated with nausea and vomiting, on clinical examination the patient had necks stiffness and right sided ptosis. Rest of the neurological examination was normal. What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
SAH caused by Berry aneurysm rupture is characterized by:

  • No focal neurological deficit
  • Sudden excruciating head ache ( Thunder clap headache)
  • Neck Stiffness

Blood in Sylvian fissure

questions.text: In T2 Arnold-Chiari malformation there is
questions.solution:
Chiari Malformation involve cerebellar herniation through the foramen magnum

  • Normal – up to 5 mm of cerebellar tonsillar descent
  • Chiari I - >5 mm of tonsillar descent
  • Chiari II – Descent of the tonsils and vermis

questions.text: Clipping and coiling methods are employed for
questions.solution: Looped titanium coils are placed inside the aneurysm dome. Due to coil migration surgical clipping is believed to results in a more definitive cure.

questions.text: A 27 yr male, on treatment with lithium, visited OPD and complaints of decreased libido. Which of the following drugs should not be administered for this patient?
questions.solution:
Aspirin (240 mg – administered daily), and PDE-V inhibitors (Sildenafil) can be administered for treating ED among lithium patients.

Though Indomethacin is effective, it also increases reabsorption of lithium from PCT causing drug accumulation leading onto toxicity symptoms, so its avoided.

choices.text: The Facial Lesion commonly involves Opthalmic Division of Trigeminal Nerve
Cortical, Gyriform Calcification and Glaucoma are common
Hemiatrophy of Brain is seen on same side of the facial mark

questions.text:
A Young Child presents with seizures, refractory to medication,He is mentally retarded and shows focal neurological deficits on examination,He has a peculiar purple-red mark on one side of his face since birth. CT scan is obtained and the image is given below

All are True about this childs condition except?
questions.solution:
• The Given image and clinical history of the child suggests the diagnosis of Sturge Weber Syndrome
  • It is a sporadic nonhereditary disorder
  • It is charecterised by Port wine stain on the face involving ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve, Glaucoma, leptomeningeal angiomas,Cortical Gyriform Calcifications, Hemiatrophy of Brain, and seizures contralateral to portwine stain

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with presents with seizures, He had recently developed headache and frequent vomitings. On examination he has papilledema. He is afebrile. CT head shows a hypodense area in the left frontal lobe .MRI brain shows a irregular lesion showing necrotic areas within and thick peripheral enhancement. The lesion is seen infiltrating the Genu of corpus callosum and extending into right hemisphere, No calcification is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The elderly male patient showing signs of increased ICT with imaging showing a infiltrative lesion with peripheral wall enhancement invading corpus callosum crossing midline is suggestive of Glioblastoma Multiformis

questions.text: A 2 year old child presents with seizures and a scalp swelling which has been increasing in size since past few months, He has a history of fall with head injury 6 months back, NCCT Head at the time of head injury showed fracture of parietal bone. CT scan taken now is shown below.what is the Likely Diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Leptomeningeal cysts, also known asgrowing skull fractures,are an enlarging skull fracture that occurs post-trauma
  • majority occur in children <3 years and can present with
  • enlarging scalp mass
  • seizures
  • focal neurological deficits and headache
  • CT scan is the modality of choice for the evaluation of leptomeningeal cyst.
  • It consists of a lytic calvarial lesion with scalloped edges, in which encephalomalacia in vaginates.

questions.text: A 30 year old male presents with sudden onset of high fever, headache, confusion and seizures, Mri shows hyperintensities in bilateral temporal lobes, probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution: • Most common site for Herpes encephalitis is Temporal Lobe.

questions.text: A 3 year old female child presents with seizures and signs of increased ICT, Her past history reveals that she is on antiarrhythmic drugs, and her General Examination shows following skin lesions, Her CT scan revealed a lesion at the Foramen of Monro What other finding can be associated in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient is suffering from Tuberous sclerosis
  • The Most common finding is the presence of Hypopigmented patches over the trunk suggestive of Ash-Leaf Macules
  • The lesion at foramen of Monro is SEGA(Subependymal Giant cell Astrocytoma)
  • Cardiac lesions can be Cardiac Rhabdomyomas which can be the reason the child was on Antiarrhytmic drugs
  • Cns lesions like cortical tubers,subependymal calcifications and SEGA are associated leading to seizures and features of raised ICT
  • Lungs can show presence of Multiple lung cysts suggestive of Lymphangioleiomyomatosis in later stages of the disease
  • Angiofibromas of the face (Adenoma Sebacium ) are common findings in these patients

Kidneys can show Bilateral Angiomyolipomas

questions.text: The Following Sequence of MRI done in a unconscious Patient who met with a Road Traffic Accident is?
questions.solution:
• Susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) is a high-spatial-resolution 3D gradient-echo MR imaging technique that accentuates the paramagnetic properties of blood and detects microhemorrhages
  • It is also sensitive sequence to look for venous bleed ,iron, hemosiderin and calcifications .
  • SWI in a patient with Diffuse axonal injury depicts Small hemorrhagic shearing injuries in the left frontal subcortical white matter (arrows) right subinsular region, and left splenium

questions.text: A patient complaining of headache underwent a CT scan which shows a solid-cystic Lesion with calcification in sellar region, Mri of the lesion shows T1 hyperintensities, Probable Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• The above shown CT image is of craniopharyngioma
  • Craniopharyngiomas are solid cystic and most common calcyfying brain tumors.

Craniopharyngioma

  • Solid cystic lesion
  • Supercellar lesion with sellar extension
  • M/C calcifying brain tumors
  • Appears hyperintense on T1 because of presence of mucin rich

Machine oil like proteinaceous content.

questions.text: A patient recovering from a traumatic injury to the face now finds himself unable to chew his food. On physical examination, his jaw deviates to the right side. The nerve that has been injured in this patient exits the skull through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution: All the given feature indicate that Mandibular nerve is involved hence Foramen ovale is correct

choices.text: Chorda tympani in the middle ear cavity

questions.text: A 46 years old man complains of dryness of the mouth. On examination he lack salivary secretion form the submandibular gland. This indicates a lesion of which of the following nervous structures?
questions.solution: Because Chorda tympani carries the salivary fibers to submandibular gland

questions.text: Which stain is used for measuring the density of neurons
questions.solution:
Nissyl staining: neurons

Glial fibers- Holzer’s stain

Mylien: luxol fast blue

choices.text: Increased discharge of noradrenergic neurons in the locus ceruleus
Increased discharge of serotonergic neurons in the midbrain raphe
Decreased adenosine levels in the reticular formation
Hypothalamic dysfunction with decreased CSF levels of orexins

questions.text: A 24-year-old man complains of fatigue, increased daytime somnolence, and periodic sudden loss of muscle tone. Polysomnography confirms the diagnosis of narcolepsy. Narcolepsy is associated with which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Narcolepsy is associated with low CSF levels of the orexins and a defect in one of the receptors for orexins (hypocretins) in the hypothalamus.

Adenosine induces sleep and serotonin agonists suppress sleep. Fatal familial insomnia is a progressive prion disease, characterized by worsening insomnia, impaired autonomic and motor functions, dementia, and death.

questions.text: An 86-year-old woman develops unilateral vesicular eruption on the trunk in a T8 dermatomal pattern. Flourescent staining of the skin scrapings confirms a diagnosis of herpes zoster. The woman complains of significant pain, as well as increased sensitivity to touch. Which of the following receptors is responsible for measuring the intensity of a steady pressure on the skin surface ?
questions.solution:
The Ruffini ending is a tonic receptor that produces a train of action potentials proportional to the intensity of pressure applied to the skin.

The Pacinian corpuscle is a very rapidly adapting receptor that fires once or twice in response to skin deformation, but can produce a continuous train of action potentials if the stimulus is repetitively applied and withdrawn.

Therefore, the Pacinian corpuscle is used to encode vibration.

choices.text: The contraction of airway smooth muscle
The strength of ventricular muscle contraction
The rate of depolarization in the SA node
The transport of calcium into skeletal muscle fibers

questions.text: A 16-year-old, highly allergic girl who is stung by a bee gives herself a shot of epinephrine prescribed by her physician. Because epinephrine activates b-adrenergic receptors, it will relieve the effects of the bee sting by decreasing which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine (adrenalin) acts on both aandb-adrenergic receptors, but has a greater affinity for b-adrenergic receptors.

Activation of b2-adrenergic receptors leads to relaxation of smooth muscle in the bronchi, vasculature, intestine, uterus, and bladder, to increased pancreatic insulin and glucagon secretion, and an increase in liver glycogenolysis.

The bronchodilator effects of epinephrine are key in the treatment of the life threatening effects of anaphylactic shock.

Activation of b1andb2-adrenergic receptors in the heart leads to an increase in the rate of SA nodal phase 4 depolarization and thus heart rate (positive chronotropic response), an increase in contractility (positive inotropic response), an increase in conduction velocity

(positive dromotropic response), and an increase in cardiac excitability/irritability.

The transport of Ca2+ into skeletal muscle fibers is nt affected by b receptors. The effects of epinephrine-induced b-adrenergic receptor activation are due to G-protein mediated activation of adenylate cyclase, which catalyzes the formation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) and activation of protein kinase A.

choices.text: The relative refractory period of nerve cells
The upstroke velocity of nerve cell action potentials
The downstroke velocity of nerve cell action potentials
The magnitude of the overshoot in nerve cell action potentials

questions.text: A 52-year-old male was given a shot of procaine prior to oral surgery to extract an abcessed tooth. Preventing the inactivation of sodium channels by local anesthetics will decrease which of the following ?
questions.solution:
The sodium-potassium pump uses the energy contained in ATP to maintain the sodium gradient across the membrane. The sodium gradient, in turn, is used to transport other substances across the membrane.

For example, the Na/Ca exchanger uses the energy in the sodium gradient to help maintain the low intracellular calcium required for normal cell function.

Although sodium enters the cell during an action potential, the quantity of sodium is so small that no significant change in intracellular sodium concentration occurs.

Because the sodium transference is so low, the sodium equilibrium potential is not an important determinant of the resting membrane potential.

questions.text: Which of the following is less during the overshoot of an action potential than during the resting state ?
questions.solution:
During an action potential, the conductances for sodium and for potassium are higher than at rest.

However, the conductance for sodium is higher than the conductance for potassium during the overshoot; as a result, the transference for potassium is less.

Recall that transference is a measure of an ion’s relative conductance: TNa = gNa/(gNa + gK) and TK = gK/(gNa + gK) where T = transference and g = conductance.

choices.text: The capacitance of the nerve fiber membrane is increased
The duration of the refractory period is increased
The potassium conductance of the membrane is increased
The amount of sodium entering the nerve with each action potentialincreases

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with a history of diplopia and paresthesia is diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (MS). MS is a demyelinating disease characterized by a failure of nerve conduction. Immersion of an affected limb in a cold bath restores nerve conduction in many of these patients. The explanation often cited for this effect is that cold increases the duration of the action potential. Which of the following best explains why increasing the duration of the action potential can restore nerve conduction in patients with MS ?
questions.solution:
In order for propagation of an action potential to occur, the depolarization produced by one action potential must depolarize the adjacent patch of excitable membrane to the threshold level.

In demyelinating diseases, such as multiple sclerosis, too much charge leaks from the membrane and as a result, not enough charge is available to bring the next patch of membrane to threshold.

Increasing the duration of the action potential increases the amount of charge entering the cell and therefore increases the probability that the next patch of excitable membrane will be depolarized to threshold.

Increasing the duration of the refractory period will not affect the amount of charge entering the cell.

Depolarizing the membrane and increasing potassium conductance will make it more difficult to produce an action potential.

If membrane capacitance is increased, the amount of charge required to excite the next patch of membrane will be increased.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male, who became ill after eating mushrooms, is brought to the Emergency Department, where he is treated for muscarinic poisoning. Which of the following signs is consistent with muscarinic poisoning ?
questions.solution:
Muscarine binds to acetylcholine muscarinic receptors on cardiac and smooth muscle.

These are the same receptors activated by the release of acetylcholine by

the vagus nerve.

Cardiac muscarinic receptors decrease the rate of phase 4 depolarization and therefore, decrease the heart rate.

A heart rate less than 60 beats per minute is called bradycardia.

Acetylcholine receptors on the skeletal muscle end plate are nicotinic receptors and do not respond to muscarine.

Dilation of the pupils and hypertension are signs of sympathetic, not parasympathetic activity.

questions.text: A fireman suffers extensive burns, resulting in a fluid and electrolyte imbalance. Which of the following conditions will produce a decrease in the magnitude of a nerve membrane action potential ?
questions.solution:
The upstroke of the action potential is caused by an inward flow of sodium ions, and therefore its magnitude depends on the extracellular sodium concentration

Decreasing the external Na+ concentration decreases the size of the action potential, but has little effect on the resting membrane potential because the permeability of the membrane to Na+ at rest is low.

Conversely, increasing the external K+ concentration decreases the resting membrane potential.

Changes in external Ca2+ concentration affect the excitability of nerve and muscle cells, but not the magnitude of the resting potential or the action potential.

choices.text: The magnitude of its resting potential
The duration of its refractory period
The conduction velocity of its action potential
The overshoot of its action potential

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics of an axon is most dependent on its diameter ?
questions.solution:
The conduction velocity of an action potential along an axon is proportional to the axon’s diameter for both unmyelinated and myelinated axons.

The resting membrane potential, the duration of the relative refractory period, and the magnitude of the action potential are dependent on the type and density of electrically excitable gates and the ability of the Na+,K+-ATPase to establish and maintain the concentration gradients.

These characteristics are not related in any systematic way to the axon diameter.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with muscular weakness and fatigue, as well as ptosis and diplopia, with worsening of symptoms as the day progresses. An MRI of the chest shows enlargement of the thymus gland. The neuropathy of myasthenia gravis is caused by antibodies against which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease in which circulating antibodies against the postsynaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptor destroy the receptors and/or prevent acetylcholine from binding.

As a result, the end-plate potential is decreased at the neuromuscular junction, causing weakness and fatigue of skeletal muscles.

Approximately 75% of patients with myasthenia gravis have thymic hyperplasia, and may benefit from thymectomy.

Other treatments for myasthenia gravis include anticholinesterase medications, immunosuppressive agents, and plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulin.
